newsitem.title: GERMANY: Toepfer sees lower wheat trade activity in 1996/97.
newsitem.headline: Toepfer sees lower wheat trade activity in 1996/97.

text.p: Global wheat trade should fall in 1996/97 amid declining import orders from China, German trader Alfred Toepfer said in its newsletter on Friday.
It put global imports at 90.5 million tonnes, compared with 92.6 million in the 1995/96 season.
China was likely to reduce imports by four million tonnes to eight million as its 1996 crop rose by five million tonnes to 107 million.
Ouptut losses in Eastern Europe would not result in additional world market demand, it added.
Russia was likely to keep wheat imports steady at 2.0-2.5 million tonnes. Its total grains crop was expected to rise to about 73 million tonnes, and domestic demand was stagnant.
Most of its wheat imports would come from Kazakhstan, and Russia might have an exportable feed barley surplus.
Ukraine would be able to shrug off a wheat crop reduction of 2.5 million tonnes to 14 million because domestic consumption was still declining.
Toepfer said Ukraine might import bread wheat to make up for quality shortfalls but might export feed wheat, feed barley, feed peas and sunflower.
Wheat demand losses would hit exporters in the U.S., Canada, Argentina, Australia and the EU.
These countries had expanded wheat areas for 1996, especially Argentina, where the 1996 crop might be up five million tonnes at 14 million.
Against this background, the world market could easily cope with a lower than expected U.S. wheat harvest, which would reduce U.S. exports to 26.5 million tonnes from 33.8 million.
Toepfer said world feed grain markets would be tighter than wheat in 1996/97, but demand should be stagnant and prices might ease along with those of wheat.
The trader cited higher barley availability, which might help offset maize shortfalls if U.S. corn output proved to be lower than expected.
Also, Argentina would produce more maize this year and China might reduce imports to a minimum.
